a: Elements in which the last electron enters the $\mathbf{(n-1)d}$ subshell. They are located in Groups 3-12 of the periodic table.

The configuration is $\mathbf{[\text{Noble Gas}] (n-1)d^{1-10} ns^{0-2}}$.
(Note: $ns^0$ is seen in $\text{Pd}$).
Defined as elements which have an incompletely filled $d$-orbital in their ground state or in any one of their common oxidation states.
They have a completely filled $\mathbf{(n-1)d^{10}}$ configuration in their ground state and in their common $+2$ oxidation state. They are $d$-block, but not T.M.s.
$[Ar] \mathbf{3d^5 4s^1}$ (Not $3d^4 4s^2$). This configuration provides extra stability due to the half-filled $d^5$ subshell.
$[Ar] \mathbf{3d^{10} 4s^1}$ (Not $3d^9 4s^2$). This configuration provides extra stability due to the fully-filled $d^{10}$ subshell.

1. Decreases from $\text{Sc} \to \text{Cr}$ (increasing $\text{Z}_{eff}$).
2. Almost constant $\text{Cr} \to \text{Cu}$ ($ ext{Z}_{eff}$ balanced by $d$-electron shielding).
3. Increases at $\text{Zn}$ (due to electron-electron repulsion in the full $3d^{10}$ subshell).
Very high for T.M.s due to strong metallic bonding (involving unpaired $d$-electrons). Value peaks mid-series (e.g., $\text{V}, \text{Cr}$) where the number of unpaired $e^-$ is maximum.

Very high, peaking mid-series (e.g., $\text{Cr}$ has max m.p. in 3d) due to strong metallic bonds from unpaired $d$-electrons.
Anomaly: $\text{Mn}$ and $\text{Tc}$ have anomalously low values.
Generally increases across the series, but irregularly. The $\text{IE}_1$ of $d$-block elements is intermediate between $s$-block and $p$-block elements.

The third IE ($\text{IE}_3$) for $\text{Mn}$ is exceptionally high. This is because the electron must be removed from the highly stable $\mathbf{3d^5}$ (half-filled) configuration of $\text{Mn}^{2+}$.
The third IE ($\text{IE}_3$) for $\text{Zn}$ is also exceptionally high, as it involves removing an electron from the very stable $\mathbf{3d^{10}}$ (fully-filled) configuration of $\text{Zn}^{2+}$.

Due to the small energy difference between the $\mathbf{(n-1)d}$ and $\mathbf{ns}$ orbitals. Both can be utilized for bonding.
Highest O.S. is $\text{Mn} (\mathbf{+7})$ in $\text{MnO}_4^{-}$.
Both ions are very stable as they possess the $\mathbf{d^5}$ (half-filled) configuration.
$\text{Sc}^{3+}$ is stable (noble gas $\mathbf{d^0}$ config). $\text{Zn}^{2+}$ is stable (pseudo-noble gas $\mathbf{d^{10}}$ config).

Generally become less negative (more 'noble') across the series. However, $\text{Mn}$, $\text{Ni}$, $\text{Zn}$ have more negative $E^\circ$ values than anticipated due to their high $\text{IE}$ and low $\Delta H_{\text{hyd}}$.

The high energy required for atomization and ionization ($\Delta H_{\text{atom}} + \text{IE}_1 + \text{IE}_2$) is NOT sufficiently compensated by the high hydration enthalpy ($\Delta H_{\text{hyd}}$) of $\text{Cu}^{2+}$.
The reduction $\text{Mn}^{3+} \to \text{Mn}^{2+}$ is highly favourable because the product $\text{Mn}^{2+}$ has the very stable $\mathbf{d^5}$ (half-filled) configuration.

$$ \mu = \sqrt{n(n+2)} \ \text{B.M.} $$
Where $n$ is the number of unpaired electrons and B.M. stands for Bohr Magnetons.

The $3d^6$ configuration has $\mathbf{4}$ unpaired electrons ($n=4$).
$$ \mu = \sqrt{4(4+2)} = \sqrt{24} \approx \mathbf{4.90 \ \text{B.M.}} $$

Due to $\mathbf{d-d}$ electron transitions. Unpaired $d$-electrons absorb energy from visible light to jump to a higher-energy $d$-orbital. The observed color is the complementary color of the light absorbed.
They have no unpaired $d$-electrons (empty or full $d$-orbitals). Since $d-d$ transitions are not possible, they cannot absorb visible light.

Colour is due to Ligand to Metal Charge Transfer (LMCT), not $d-d$ transition. An electron is momentarily transferred from a filled ligand orbital ($\text{O}^{2-}$) to an empty metal orbital ($\text{Mn}^{7+}$).

Compounds formed when small non-metal atoms ($ ext{H}, ext{C}, ext{N}$) get trapped in the voids (interstices) of the metal lattice.
1. Very high m.p. 2. Extremely hard (e.g., tungsten carbides). 3. Retain metallic conductivity. 4. Chemically inert.

T.M.s have similar atomic radii (due to Lanthanoid contraction and $d$-block trends), allowing atoms of one metal to easily substitute the atoms of another in the crystal lattice. E.g., Brass ($ ext{Cu/Zn}$).

$$ 2\text{CrO}_4^{2-} \text{(Yellow)} + 2\text{H}^+ \rightleftharpoons \text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} \text{(Orange)} + \text{H}_2\text{O} $$
Dichromate ($ ext{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-}$) is stable in acidic medium; Chromate ($ ext{CrO}_4^{2-}$) is stable in basic medium.
$$ 4\text{FeCr}_2\text{O}_4 + 8\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + 7\text{O}_2 \xrightarrow{\text{Fusion}} 8\text{Na}_2\text{CrO}_4 + 2\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3 + 8\text{CO}_2 $$
It consists of two tetrahedral $\text{CrO}_4$ units joined by sharing one oxygen atom (Cr-O-Cr bridge). The $\text{Cr}-\text{O}-\text{Cr}$ bond angle is $\approx 126^\circ$.

$$ \text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} + 14\text{H}^+ + 6e^- \to 2\text{Cr}^{3+} + 7\text{H}_2\text{O} $$
The chromium oxidation state changes from $\mathbf{+6}$ to $\mathbf{+3}$.
$$ \text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-} + 14\text{H}^+ + 6\text{Fe}^{2+} \to 2\text{Cr}^{3+} + 6\text{Fe}^{3+} + 7\text{H}_2\text{O} $$

$$ 2\text{MnO}_2 + 4\text{KOH} + \text{O}_2 \xrightarrow{\text{Fusion}} 2\text{K}_2\text{MnO}_4 + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} $$
Forms the Green Manganate ion ($\mathbf{\text{MnO}_4^{2-}}$), where $\text{Mn}$ is in the $\mathbf{+6}$ O.S.

Disproportionation in acidic/neutral solution:
$$ 3\text{MnO}_4^{2-} + 4\text{H}^+ \to 2\text{MnO}_4^{-} + \text{MnO}_2 + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} $$
Forms the Purple Permanganate ion ($\mathbf{\text{MnO}_4^{-}}$).

$$ \text{MnO}_4^{-} + 8\text{H}^+ + 5e^- \to \text{Mn}^{2+} + 4\text{H}_2\text{O} $$
Manganese O.S. changes from $\mathbf{+7}$ to $\mathbf{+2}$ (5 electrons).
$$ 2\text{MnO}_4^{-} + 5\text{C}_2\text{O}_4^{2-} + 16\text{H}^+ \to 2\text{Mn}^{2+} + 10\text{CO}_2 + 8\text{H}_2\text{O} $$

$$ \text{MnO}_4^{-} + 2\text{H}_2\text{O} + 3e^- \to \text{MnO}_2 + 4\text{OH}^- $$
Manganese O.S. changes from $\mathbf{+7}$ to $\mathbf{+4}$ (3 electrons). Forms $\text{MnO}_2$ precipitate.

q: O.S. change of $\text{Mn}$ in $\mathbf{\text{KMnO}_4}$ in Acidic, Neutral, and Strongly Basic media.
a:
1. Acidic: $\text{Mn}^{+7} \to \text{Mn}^{+2}$ (5 electrons)
2. Neutral/Weakly Basic: $\text{Mn}^{+7} \to \text{Mn}^{+4}$ (3 electrons)
3. Strongly Basic: $\text{Mn}^{+7} \to \text{Mn}^{+6}$ (1 electron, forms $\text{MnO}_4^{2-}$)
The steady, gradual decrease in atomic and ionic radii ($\text{Ln}^{3+}$) across the Lanthanoid series (from $\text{Ce}$ to $\text{Lu}$).

Due to the poor shielding effect of the $\mathbf{4f}$ electrons. As the nuclear charge increases, the $4f$ electrons fail to effectively shield the outer $6s$ electrons, pulling them closer to the nucleus.

The radii of the elements in the $4d$ and $5d$ transition series are almost identical (e.g., $\text{Zr} \approx \text{Hf}$). This leads to very similar chemical properties and makes their separation difficult.
Basicity of $\text{Ln}(\text{OH})_3$ decreases from $\text{La}(\text{OH})_3$ to $\text{Lu}(\text{OH})_3$ due to the decreasing ionic size and resulting increase in covalent character.
$\mathbf{+3}$ is the most common and stable O.S. for all Lanthanoids.

These O.S. occur when they lead to a stable $\mathbf{f^0}$ (e.g., $\text{Ce}^{4+}$), $\mathbf{f^7}$ (e.g., $\text{Eu}^{2+}$, $\text{Tb}^{4+}$), or $\mathbf{f^{14}}$ (e.g., $\text{Yb}^{2+}$) configuration.
An important alloy consisting of $\approx 95\%$ Lanthanoid metals (mainly $\text{Ce}$) and $\approx 5\%$ $\text{Fe}$ (plus traces of S, C, Ca, Al). Used in lighter flints.

q: Why do Actinoids show a greater range of O.S.?
a: Due to the very small energy gap between the $\mathbf{5f, 6d,}$ and $\mathbf{7s}$ orbitals, allowing all these electrons to participate in bonding (e.g., $\text{Np}$ and $\text{Pu}$ can show up to $+7$ O.S.).
$\mathbf{5f}$ orbitals have even poorer shielding than $\mathbf{4f}$ orbitals, leading to a stronger 'Actinoid Contraction' and more significant bonding involvement.
Actinoids are far more reactive (e.g., with acids, $\text{H}_2\text{O}$) than Lanthanoids, especially in finely divided form. Additionally, all Actinoids are radioactive.
